stem_html: What is the observed frequency when the source having frequency 3.0\,\text{kHz} is moving towards the observer at a speed of 1.0\times 10^2\,\text{m}/\text{s} and the speed of sound is 331\,\text{m/s}?

answers.content_html: The Doppler effect is a change in the observed speed of a sound due to the relative motion between the source and the observer.
answers.feedback_html: The Doppler effect is a not a change in the observed speed of the sound, it is a change in observed frequency.

answers.content_html: The Doppler effect is a change in the observed frequency of a sound due to the relative motion between the source and the observer.
answers.feedback_html: Yes, it is a change in the observed frequency of a sound due to the relative motion between the source and the observer.

answers.content_html: The Doppler effect is a change in the observed intensity of a sound due to the relative motion between the source and the observer.
answers.feedback_html: It is a change in the observed frequency of the sound due to the relative motion between the source and the observer.

answers.content_html: The Doppler effect is a change in the observed timbre of a sound, due to the relative motion between the source and the observer.
answers.feedback_html: No, it is not the change in the observed timbre of a sound.

answers.content_html: It is a destructive interference of sound created by an object moving faster than sound.
answers.feedback_html: It is not a destructive interference; it is a constructive interference of sound created by an object moving faster than sound.

answers.content_html: It is a constructive interference of sound created by an object moving faster than sound.
answers.feedback_html: Yes, a sonic boom is constructive interference of sound created by an object moving faster than sound.

answers.content_html: It is a destructive interference of sound created by an object moving slower than sound.
answers.feedback_html: A sonic boom is a constructive interference of sound created by an object moving faster than sound.

answers.content_html: It is a constructive interference of sound created by an object moving slower than sound.
answers.feedback_html: A constructive interference can occur if the source of sound is moving faster than the speed of the sound.

answers.content_html: It approaches zero. This is because all wave crests are superimposed on one another through constructive interference.
answers.feedback_html: Due to constructive interference, the amplitude of the sound approaches infinity.

answers.content_html: It approaches infinity. This is because all wave crests are superimposed on one another through constructive interference.
answers.feedback_html: Yes, it approaches infinity because all wave crests are superimposed on one another through constructive interference.

answers.content_html: It approaches zero, because all wave crests are superimposed on one another through destructive interference.
answers.feedback_html: When the speed of the source matches the speed of sound, then constructive interference occurs.

answers.content_html: It approaches infinity, because all wave crests are superimposed on one another through destructive interference.
answers.feedback_html: There will be constructive interference due to which the amplitude of the sound approaches infinity.

stem_html: When the speed of the source matches the speed of sound, what happens to the amplitude of the sound wave? Why?

answers.content_html: speed of the source
answers.feedback_html: A sonic boom occurs when the speed of the source approaches that of sound.

answers.content_html: frequency of source
answers.feedback_html: A sonic boom can occur with waves of any frequency.

answers.content_html: amplitude of source
answers.feedback_html: A sonic boom can occur with waves of any amplitude.

answers.content_html: distance of observer from the source
answers.feedback_html: Observers can experience sonic booms at various distances.

stem_html: What does the occurrence of the sonic boom depend on?

answers.content_html: No, a sonic boom is created only when the source exceeds the speed of sound.
answers.feedback_html: An object travelling at supersonic speed will continually displace air and will, therefore, continually produce sonic booms.

answers.content_html: Yes, sonic booms continue to be created when an object is traveling at supersonic speeds.
answers.feedback_html: Objects travelling at supersonic speeds continue to make sonic booms as they travel, because they are constantly displacing air.
